item.dc:creator: Susan Vanderplas
item.description:
Today is the last day that UNL is allowing public comments about program closures, so Iâ€™ve been having a bit of fun shitposting comments on behalf of the departments proposed for closure. This started when I asked ChatGPT to generate a not-the-onion post about the statistics department being closed due to the UNL administrationâ€™s bad use of statistics. Iâ€™ve and edited and annotated the statistics version (and changed names and positions at will to reflect administrators â€“ departmental characters are all as GPT generated them).

For other departments, I have largely left the poems unedited.

Statistics

University Administration Uses Faulty Statistics to Justify Eliminating Statistics Department

â€œP-Value Was Below Our Standards for Caring,â€ Says Chancellor

In a move described by many as â€œpoetically idiotic,â€ the administration of Midwestern State University announced Monday its plan to eliminate the Department of Statisticsâ€”citing a data analysis later revealed to have been performed using Microsoft Excelâ€™s AutoSum function.

According to the administrationâ€™s official report1, â€œa thorough statistical analysisâ€ demonstrated that the department was â€œstatistically insignificantâ€ to the universityâ€™s mission. When pressed for details, Chancellor Bodney Rennett clarified, â€œThe p-value was really highâ€”like, I think, 70 or 80 percentâ€”so weâ€™re confident this was the right call.â€

Faculty members within the Statistics Department expressed mixed feelings ranging from disbelief to the quiet satisfaction of being proven right one last time.

â€œThey told us they ran a regression model,â€ said Dr. Alan Brooks, head of the department. â€œThen we found out they just drew a line through a scatterplot and said, â€˜Looks flat enough.â€™ Iâ€™m not even madâ€”thatâ€™s almost elegant in its ignorance.â€2

The universityâ€™s analysis reportedly concluded that student interest in statistics had â€œdeclined by 200%â€ over the past decade. When asked how a percentage could exceed 100%, the administration explained that â€œit just means students are twice as uninterested.â€3

Administrators also cited â€œstrong anecdotal dataâ€ from a campus-wide survey showing low awareness of the departmentâ€™s existence. However, the survey was distributed exclusively to the football team during spring break.

â€œWe stand by our numbers,â€ said Bark Mutton, Executive Vice Chancellor of Academic Optimization. â€œWe even used one of those fancy pivot thingies. The results were clear: no one knows what a median is, and thatâ€™s the departmentâ€™s fault.â€

Dosh Javis, Associate Chancellor of Strategic Analytics (Business Edition), supported the decision. â€œOur chi-squared test came out looking real weird, which probably means itâ€™s significant,â€ Javis said. â€œWe confirmed this by looking at the vibes.â€

In response, the department offered to teach the administration how to correctly analyze the data4â€”an offer the administration declined on the grounds that â€œit sounded expensive and mathy.â€5

Rumors suggest the university will reallocate the departmentâ€™s funding to expand the Business Analytics program, which â€œdoes the same thing, but with prettier dashboards.â€

Students and alumni have since launched a petition to save the department, though early analysis indicates it may not be effective: the administration reportedly used a random number generator to sample the signatures and found â€œinsufficient support.â€6

As for the soon-to-be-dismantled statisticians, they remain philosophical.

â€œIn the end,â€ Dr. Brooks said, â€œthis outcome was predictable. The confidence interval for administrative understanding of statistics has always included zero.â€

When asked whether the administration had any regrets, Chancellor Rennett sighed. â€œIf weâ€™ve learned anything,â€ he said, â€œitâ€™s that we probably should have hired some statisticians before getting rid of them.â€

This one is by Copilot, who managed to win me over by asking if I wanted more biting, darker academic satire. Yes, please.

In the ivory halls of U. Prestige,
Where tenure once bloomed like academic trees,
The Stats Department stood, austere and proud,
Till the Admins arrived with a thunderous crowd.

â€œWeâ€™ve crunched the numbers!â€ the Provost proclaimed,
Though the spreadsheet he held was half unnamed.
â€œOur models are lean, our metrics divineâ€”
We forecast success with a sigmoid line!â€

The Chancellor nodded, eyes glazed with delight,
I skimmed a report late last Tuesday night.
It said that statistics are costly and slowâ€”
Weâ€™d rather have metrics that sparkle and glow!â€

The VP of Optics, with PowerPoint flair,
Declared, â€œWeâ€™ve benchmarked against thin air!
Our sample was small, our bias was grand,
But the graphs were in color, so wasnâ€™t it planned?â€

The statisticians, pale and aghast,
Whispered of errors both present and past.
â€œYouâ€™ve p-hacked your way through a forest of lies,
And called it a garden of data-driven skies!â€

â€œYouâ€™ve tortured the numbers till they confessed,
Then cited the ones that looked best-dressed.
Youâ€™ve modeled with noise, ignored the base rate,
And called it precision â€” how terribly great!â€

But the Admins, drunk on dashboards and spin,
Said, â€œTruth is a cost we wonâ€™t tuck in.
Weâ€™ll cut the department, itâ€™s old and itâ€™s grayâ€”
Weâ€™ll hire influencers to model our way!â€

So the statisticians packed up their code,
Their R scripts, their ethics, their epistemic load.
They left behind silence, a void in the halls,
Where once lived the guardians of rigorous calls.

Now decisions are made by a dartboard of dreams,
And budgets are balanced by marketing memes.
The campus is ruled by a stochastic fog,
Where causation is chased by a data-trained dog.

And deep in the archives, behind a locked door,
A dusty old textbook weeps on the floor.
It whispers of variance, of truth and of testâ€”
Of a time when the numbers were handled with zest.

So heed this tale, ye scholars of fate:
When stats are discarded, decay wonâ€™t wait.
For truth is a candle, and ignorance windâ€”
And the flame dies fast when the fools are grinned.

Earth and Atmospheric Science

â€œOn the Miscalculation of Cloudsâ€

They gathered their spreadsheets, the suits and the deans,
Projecting the budget in tidy routines.
With pivot tables polished and charts full of flair,
They proved, beyond doubt, that the weatherâ€™s â€œnot there.â€

â€œThe data are clear,â€ said the Vice of Finance,
â€œFewer majors in rain, no statistical chance!
Why fund a department that studies the sky,
When clouds donâ€™t contribute to ROI?â€

The models were neat â€” though a tad underfit,
Theyâ€™d left out the columns that didnâ€™t quite fit:
Like storms, and droughts, and hurricanesâ€™ spin,
And the carbon line creeping up from within.

They missed the confounder (a common mistake) â€”
That learning the Earth helps the earth not to break.
A p-value of folly, a confidence low,
Yet onward they marched, with â€œefficiencyâ€ glow.

So the forecast was wrong â€” as forecasts can be,
But this one brought silence where there once was degree.
No one to track rainfall, or warn of the flood,
No one to note ice where once there was mud.

And somewhere, a spreadsheet, still smug and precise,
Lists â€œcost savingsâ€ in rows, and forgets the true price.
For when data are twisted to fit oneâ€™s desire,
You may balance the books â€” but to the world youâ€™ll set fire.

Educational Administration

â€œThe Day They Cut the Ed Adminsâ€

They crunched all the numbers, they tallied, they totted,
They trimmed and they slashed and they proudly allotted.
â€œThe budgetâ€™s too tight!â€ cried the Chancellorâ€™s crew,
â€œSo something must goâ€”letâ€™s cut what they do!â€

â€œWho needs those folks teaching how leaders should lead?
Weâ€™ve spreadsheets and slogans! Thatâ€™s all that we need!â€
They patted themselves for their clever, clean slateâ€”
While the school down the street lost its principalâ€™s gate.

For who trains the people who guide all the schools,
Who know how to nurture, not just follow rules?
Who helps the new teachers to stand up and strive,
To juggle twelve duties and keep kids alive?

The answer was simple, though none would admit:
â€™Twas the folks they just cut, who made sense of it.
So now thereâ€™s confusion from desk up to dome,
And nobodyâ€™s sure who should take the lead home.

The numbers looked lovely, the balance sheets neatâ€”
But the heart of the campus forgot how to beat.
And somewhere a dean, with a budget to mend,
Still wonders why chaos wonâ€™t neatly dead-end.

Textiles, Merchandising, and Fashion Design

Limericks on the Unraveling of Fashion

1.
A school once well-threaded with pride,
Taught fashion both clever and wide.
But cuts came one day,
And stitched it awayâ€”
Now the fabric of tradeâ€™s come untied.

2.
They claimed, â€œItâ€™s just hems and some flair,
Weâ€™ll save quite a sum if itâ€™s bare!â€
But towns lost their shops,
And payrolls took dropsâ€”
Now nothing is making it wear.

3.
The merchants cried out, â€œWhat a twist!
Our buyers and stylists are missed!â€
The mills grew all still,
The markets lost willâ€”
The spreadsheets forgot what they risked.

4.
No longer the students design
The garments that once shone so fine;
The runways are dark,
The makers remark,
â€œThat cut cost us more down the line.â€

5.
So hereâ€™s to the budgetâ€™s â€œsmartâ€ shears,
That trimmed off the work of the yearsâ€”
They saved just a dime,
But in fashionâ€™s decline,
Theyâ€™ve tailored the stateâ€™s own arrears.

Landscape Architecture

â€œThe Day They Cut the Landscapersâ€
(in the style of Dr. Seuss)

They gathered one morning, the Board and the Dean,
With coffee and charts and their spreadsheets all clean.
â€œThe numbers are down! The dollars are tight!
Weâ€™ll trim some departments to set it all right!â€

So they snipped and they clipped with administrative flair,
â€œGoodbye to the gardens! Weâ€™ve no funds to spare!â€
They smiled as they sliced through the Landscape Design,
Declaring, â€œWeâ€™ll manage just fineâ€”oh, just fine!â€

But outside the windows the campus grew sad,
The walkways all cracked and the hedges went bad.
The flowers went missing, the benches grew bare,
The sun baked the quad with a pitiless glare.

The students all sighed, â€œWhat a dusty old viewâ€”
We used to have shade! We used to have dew!â€
The squirrels packed their nuts and abandoned the green,
And weeds took the throne where the roses had been.

The town down the road felt the loss in its core,
No planners to guide how their parks could restore.
No one to think how the runoff should flow,
Or how future floods could be softened below.

The budget looked tidyâ€”at least for a yearâ€”
But soon came the drought and the landslides and fear.
For when you cut roots just to balance the sum,
You find, all too late, that the green doesnâ€™t come.

So next time youâ€™re counting your dollars and cents,
Remember: good planning is good common sense.
A landscapeâ€™s not pretty, itâ€™s how we all stayâ€”
Itâ€™s life in the soil, itâ€™s work that wonâ€™t fade away.

Community and Regional Planning

â€œWhen Planners Are Goneâ€
A Villanelle

The maps grow blank where once the futures lay,
Small towns fall silent, stripped of guiding hands;
No one remains to chart a wiser way.

The roads still twist, the river bends its sway,
But no one asks what promise each demandsâ€”
The maps grow blank where once the futures lay.

The grain elevator rusts, the youth donâ€™t stay,
Old dreams collapse like barns in drifting sands;
No one remains to chart a wiser way.

The countyâ€™s heart beats faint, its edges fray,
Forgotten voices echo through their landsâ€”
The maps grow blank where once the futures lay.

The state grows proud of savings on display,
Yet cannot count what loss the cut commands;
No one remains to chart a wiser way.

So let the record show, in dust and clay:
A vision died beneath their costed plans.
The maps grow blank where once the futures layâ€”
No one remains to chart a wiser way.

item.title: Teaching Statistical Computing with R and Python
item.dc:creator: Susan Vanderplas
item.description:
Abstract

Computing courses can be daunting for students for a variety of reasons, including programming anxiety, difficulty learning a programming language in a second language, and unfamiliarity with assumed computer knowledge. In an ongoing attempt to teach statistical computing effectively, I developed a textbook intended for use in a flipped classroom setting where R and Python are taught concurrently. This approach allows students to learn programming concepts applicable to most languages, while developing skills in both R and Python that can be used in an increasingly multilingual field. In this talk, I discuss the bookâ€™s design and how it integrates into a sequence of undergraduate and graduate computing courses. Along the way, we will talk about opinionated coding decisions, use of memes, comics, and YouTube tutorials, and other features integrated into this open-source textbook built with quarto and hosted on GitHub.

item.title: Hidden Multiple Comparisons Increase Forensic Error Rates
item.dc:creator: Susan Vanderplas
item.description:
Abstract

When wires are cut, the tool produces striations on the cut surface; as in other forms of forensic analysis, these striation marks are used to connect the evidence to the source that created them. The practice of comparing two wire cut surfaces introduces complexities not present in better-investigated forensic examination of toolmarks such as those observed on bullets, as wire comparisons inherently require multiple distinct comparisons, increasing the error rate. We call attention to this multiple comparison problem in wire examination, and relate it to other situations in forensics that involve multiple comparisons, such as database searches.

item.title: A Plot is Worth a Thousand Tests: Assessing Residual Diagnostics with the Lineup Protocol
item.dc:creator: Weihao (Patrick) Li, Di Cook, Emi Tanaka, Klaus Ackermann, Susan Vanderplas
item.description:
Abstract

Regression experts consistently recommend plotting residuals for model diagnosis, despite the availability of many numerical hypothesis test procedures designed to use residuals to assess problems with a model fit. Here we provide evidence for why this is good advice using data from a visual inference experiment. We show how conventional tests are too sensitive, which means that too often the conclusion would be that the model fit is inadequate. The experiment uses the lineup protocol which puts a residual plot in the context of null plots. This helps generate reliable and consistent reading of residual plots for better model diagnosis. It can also help in an obverse situation where a conventional test would fail to detect a problem with a model due to contaminated data. The lineup protocol also detects a range of departures from good residuals simultaneously.

Section on Statistical Graphics, JSM
Event Type: Conference
Location: Portland, Or

item.title: Escaping Flatland: Graphics, Dimensionality, and Human Perception
item.dc:creator: Susan Vanderplas
item.description:
Abstract

Almost 40 years ago, Cleveland & McGill published the first of 3 papers detailing experiments assessing the accuracy of numerical perception using different types of charts. This study is often cited as a reason to avoid the use of extraneous dimensions in data visualization: 2D bar charts produced more accurate estimates than 3D bar charts; in addition, lines (length) produced more accurate estimates than circles (area). Graphics have changed fairly significantly in the last 40 years: where we once had fixed 3D perspective charts, we now can rotate 3D renderings in digital space and even 3D print our charts to examine physically. Many optical illusions result from perceptual mismatches of 3D visual heuristics and 2D, planar, data representations; more realistic renderings available with modern tools might change the outcome of the Cleveland & McGill comparison of 2D vs. 3D accuracy. In this paper, we present several experiments which replicate the bar chart portion of Cleveland & McGillâ€™s original study, comparing 2D, 3D fixed perspective, 3D rendered, and 3D printed charts. We discuss the findings and the importance of replicating classic experiments using modern technology, as well as the benefits of incorporating hands-on research in introductory classes as experiential learning activities.

item.title: Graphical Perception in a Pandemic: Log Scales, Exponential Growth, and the Importance of User Testing
item.dc:creator: Susan Vanderplas, Emily Robinson, Reka Howard
item.description:
Abstract

During COVID, people all over the world were consulting time-series charts on a daily basis and using these charts to make decisions. Discussions broke out among data visualization and scientific communication experts, debating the relative merits of log and linear scales, but there was relatively little research about how people perceive and use visualizations of exponential data, with linear or transformed scales. In this talk, Iâ€™ll discuss the study we undertook to address the lack of research in this area, and how the results speak not only to the importance of additional graphical testing, but also to the trade offs between different levels of user engagement with visualizations.
